title: we commemorate the first remembrance
story: Half way through the two-minute silence a widow, still raw with grief, began to sob.By the time the buglers at the newly-unveiled Cenotaph sounded the Last Post  seconds later, nearly , people were in tears.Tomorrow, exactly a century after the Great War ended, organisers are recreating the extraordinary scenes of the first national service of remembrance in London.The year before there had been a victory parade past a temporary war memorial made of plywood.But in the summer of , the Cabinet decided that Whitehall would be at the heart of national mourning and remembrance throughout the British Empire.As well as a permanent Cenotaph to the Glorious Dead, the body of an unidentied British soldier would represent the , Tommies killed in the four-year war.His body would be buried in Westminster Abbey, the parish church of the Empire, for a grateful nation to mourn its dead.The idea came from Rev David Railton MC, a young chaplain who had served with valour on the Western Front. On October , King George V gave his consent.In the days before the Armistice, four teams of an officer and two other ranks set off in secrecy to the battlefields of Somme, Aisne, Arras and Ypres.We are now offering it free as a resource for teachers. The -page supplement won praise from Education Secretary Damian Hinds. “These stories are a brilliant way of bringing the lives of  years ago to le,” he said. “This great initiative captures the war from many dferent perspectives, useful for anyone who wants to learn or teach about it.”If you are a school or a teacher who would like copies, email us at compdept@news with the subject ‘Centenary WW Pullout’.Please indicateyou would like a downloadable version or a printed copy. If you would like a printed copy, please include your full name and address in your email. Requests must be made by midnight on November . Subject to availability.They dug up the remains of four British soldiers killed early in the war, so they would be unidentiable.Each body, carried in sacking, was examined at the Military Headquarters at St Pol, south of Calais, before being covered with a Union Flag.At just after midnight on November , Brigadier General John Wyatt, head of British Forces in France, chose one body.The Unknown Warrior would receive the respect and honours given only to princes, generals and the greatest of statesmen.The following day in Boulogne, where crowds lined the streets, his body was transferred from a pine box to a coffin hewn from a -year-old oak that once stood at Hampton Court.Under leaden skies, the Unknown Warrior passed the White Clfs of Dover aboard HMS Verdun, which sailed in silence into the dock.It was the same journey that over the four years of the war more than a million Tommies wounded in the hell of the Western Front had taken.As the train carrying his body and a barrel of soil from a French battlefield thundered through Kent, crowds gathered at every station.At London’s Victoria station he lay in state overnight, before being carried on a gun carriage to Whitehall just before am — his coffin covered in a blood-stained battlefield Union Flag.In a ceremony unchanged for  years, the Monarch and princes, surrounded by generals and politicians, waited at theCenotaph for Big Ben to strike  o’clock on Thursday, November , .In nearby Westminster Abbey, a thousand widows and mothers — all believing the Unknown Warrior was their husband or son — waited.A Times reporter inside the Abbey, wrote: “The tension was almost too great. When seconds seemed to halt people held their breath lest they be heard in the stillness. At last a woman sobbed and the breakdown helped release the tears which others had with dficulty held trembling on their eyelids. Many were weeping at the end of the two minutes.” The King — just like our Queen did for more than half a century and now Prince Charles — placed the first wreath at the Cenotaph on behalf of a grateful nation. After a short service at the Cenotaph, the Unknown Warrior’s coffin was carried into the Abbey.A tin helmet, a side-arm and the King’s wreath lay on top.The King, with his generals and admirals of the fleet, stood at the grave as the coffin was lowered and covered in the earth from the Western Front.Outside, hundreds of thousands of people waited to file past the Cenotaph. Such were the numbers that it took them up to six hours to walk the three-quarters of a mile from Trafalgar Square to Westminster Abbey.The outpouring of grief saw The Cenotaph almost buried in wreaths of mainly green and white flowers — Poppies were not introduced until the following year.In the four days that followed in , one and a quarter million grieving families filed past the Cenotaph, placing an astonishing , wreaths on the new memorial to the Glorious Dead.They carried on down Whitehall, which had been closed to traffic, to pay their respects at the grave of the Unknown Warrior.They called it the People’s Pilgrimage and the only other outpouring of grief to come near was the death of Princess Diana eight decades later.A spokesman for the Department for Digital, Culture, Media and Sport, which is responsible for arranging tomorrow’s ceremony, said: “When we saw the pictures of the first Armistice in  we wanted to create a People’s Pilgrimage for today.”So the People’s Procession was born, where descendants of the men and women who served in the Great War could remember them.The Royal British Legion held a ballot and ten thousand people won their place in the mile-long walk that starts on the Mall at .pm.They will follow the , military veterans of all conflicts who will march past the Cenotaph from .am. Those waiting in the Mall for the People’s Procession will watch the Armistice on big screens. When the walk gets under way they will be able to lay their wreaths, just like in .  Ian Kennard will be among the , modern-day participants. For Ian, , from Southampton, it is a chance to honour the grandfather he never knew. Private Henry Joseph Moody, of the th battalion Royal Fusiliers, was in the Battle of the Somme in .In the early hours of November , he was lost on patrol in fog and his body never found.In , Ian and his two brothers placed a cross at the spot where he vanished. Tomorrow he will lay another cross at the Cenotaph.Ian says: “I knew nothing about him until  when I was given his medals from an aunt. I feel so proud of him.”English teacher Janine Creaney, from Canterbury, Kent, and her niece Olivia will be walking in honour of her grandfather Frederick Edwards, from London’s Canning Town.He lied to enlist and his mother, Martha, had him brought back. He went back two years later and was wounded in the hand. He lived to be .Janine says: “It will be an honour to remember him on Sunday.”LORD Mayor’s Parade, London.Fields of Remembrance: Westminster Abbey Cardf Castle Saltwell Park, Gateshead National Arboretum, Staffs Belfast City Hall Lydiard Park, Royal Wootton Bassett, Wilts.am-pm: Shrouds of the Somme, Olympic Park, East London. On until November . Free..pm: Twickenham at half time in the England v New Zealand rugby international, fans will watch a film made by former flanker Lewis Moody, who lost three great uncles in World War One who have no graves.pm-pm: , flames will be lit at the Tower of London in the showpiece Beyond The Deepening Shadow..pm, BBC : British Legion Festival of Remembrance from the Royal Albert Hall, attended by the Royal Family, will feature Sir Tom Jones, Sheridan Smith and Michael Palin.REMEMBRANCE Day will start at am with bagpipers in , locations across the UK and Commonwealth playing the traditional lament, Battle’s O’er.In Mons, Belgium,  bike riders will set off on a sponsored cycle ride to London, via Ypres.Also from am and throughout the day, giant portraits of local war heroes will be etched into the sand at  beaches around the UK for Danny Boyle’s Pages Of The Sea national event. The public can also make beach drawings to pay tribute to loved ones who served in the Great War.In Folkestone, Kent, a ft x ft portrait of war poet Wilfred Owen will be etched in the beach at Sunny Sands..am: London’s Olympic Park will fall silent for a service of Remembrance at the Shrouds of the Somme. Families of the , Tommies whose bodies were never found are expected to be there.am: National two-minute silence led by the Royal Family at the Cenotaph in Whitehall. Prince Charles will again lay a wreath on behalf of the Queen.National mourning to mark the moment the guns finally fell silent will be held at war memorials throughout the UK, including Alexandra Gardens, Cardf, and Edinburgh Castle..am: More than , Royal British Legion veterans will march past the Cenotaph, including -year-old Pte Donald Smith with the Queen’s Own Highlanders and Jeff Wilkins, , who travelled from San Diego. Calornia, to be with the Federation of RAF Apprentices and Boy Entrants..pm: The Nation’s Thank You begins with the People’s Procession, when , men, women and children with a family connection to the Great War will leave London’s Green Park and walk past the Cenotaph. It will take an hour for them all to complete the . mile route, where they can place wreaths on the national war memorial.Also at .pm, international bell ringing: Just as they did in , bells will ring out in cathedrals and churches in the UK and Europe to mark the end of the war..pm: In Edinburgh, poems by Wilfred Owen and Siegfried Sassoon will be read at a free concert on the site of the former Craiglockhart Military Hospital, where soldiers were treated for shellshock.pm: Beefeaters at the Tower of London will light the last flames of the Beyond The Deepening Shadow remembrance showpiece .pm: The Queen will attend the National Service to mark the centenary at Westminster Abbey with the Prime Minister, royals, politicians and guests.pm: A chain of , beacons will be lit from Unst, the most northerly inhabited island in the UK, to Cornwall..pm: Bells ring out as the beacons blaze throughout Britain and criers in  towns perform a “cry for peace”.SKY and BBC News will both be showing Armistice Centenary events throughout tomorrow.BBC, am-.pm: David Dimbleby and Dan Snow present coverage of the Cenotaph ceremony, veterans march- past and the People’s Procession. Highlights on BBC at pm.BBC, .pm: Forces’ sweetheart Katherine Jenkins hosts a Remembrance Sunday Songs Of Praise from Southampton.BBC, .pm: Sophie Raworth leads BBC coverage of the official Memorial Service at Westminster Abbey.BBC, .pm: Don’t miss the first TV screening of Lord of the Rings director Peter Jackson’s brilliant -minute colourised film They Shall Not Grow Old.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: james forsyth theresa may brexit day debate
story: But with the clock ticking — on Tuesday the Cabinet was meant to decide on whether to book ferry space to bring in essential supplies in the event of no deal — there is an intense scramble on to get a deal.As one government source tells me: “If there’s no November Council, then no deal goes into overdrive.”With Mrs May determined to avoid no deal, there probably will be some kind of agreement shortly. But it will be flawed –– and Mrs May should say so.I admit this sounds odd: Why would a Prime Minister admit that a deal they have negotiated isn’t great ButMrs May tries to say that this agreement is perfect, and that there is no risk of any part of the UK getting stuck in the backstop — which would leave it in an EU customs union but with no say over the trade deals the EU is doing — then she will easily be disproved.Mrs May should take a leaf out of the book of Attorney General Geoffrey Cox, who as a hugely successful trial lawyer knows a fair bit about persuading people of his case.He told Cabinet on Tuesday that when it came to quitting the backstop “a unilateral right would give the UK greater scope to establish its case, as the other side would have to prove the contrary”.But he went on to acknowledge that negotiating a unilateral right to get out of the backstop was highly unlikely in the time available and a mutual review mechanism could be made to work.Cox’s essential argument is about managing risk. Every option on Brexit now carries with it risk.The challenge is to work out how to best manage these risks. The risk with accepting a legally binding backstop in the withdrawal agreement is that the UK ends up being unable to get out of it cleanly.It would be direthe UK ended up leaving the EU in a way that tied it to the EU for ever.But set against this must be the risk of no deal, and the disruption that would cause. To make matters worse, the Government has done absurdly little to mitigate no deal.The reason that even Cabinet ministers who loathe where the negotiations are heading do not want to go for no deal is they know how unprepared the country is for it.At the same time, there is a risk thatthere is no deal, Parliament would either insist on a second referendum — that would harden isions and toxy our politics — or cancel the process altogether, creating a dangerous democratic deficit.Frankly, the argument that Mrs May’s withdrawal agreement is less bad than the alternatives will be pretty much the only thing going for it.It will be hard for her to make this argument as so many of the deal’s problems are self-inflicted.She triggered Article  without knowing what the UK wanted she has wasted much of the past  months in a negotiation with her own Cabinet the failure to plan properly for no deal has weakened the Government’s negotiating position.Even the Parliamentary arithmetic has been made worse by Mrs May. If she hadn’t called that election, there would be a Tory majority and she wouldn’t be so reliant on the DUP.But it is the argument that her deal is less bad than the alternatives that is keeping the Cabinet on board and it is her best — and, possibly, only — way of getting the House of Commons to vote for such a flawed agreement.THE bad news for Theresa May is that it doesn’t get any easier once she’s got a deal with Brussels.For she will still have to get this withdrawal agreement through the House of Commons.With the DUP unhappy and  Tory Brexit ultras expected to vote against the deal, as well as Jo Johnson and other Tories who want another referendum, it will be extremely tough to get it over the line.“I can’t quite see where the majority comes from,” admits one Cabinet minister.But there is growing talk that the way to get the deal through might be to bring it back a second time, with the markets – which expect a deal – freaking out.As this Secretary of State says: “Do you get it through the first time  Maybe not.He did little to hide his irritation at being moved from his job as universities minister because of his opposition to Mrs May’s plan to tinker with tuition fees.But his resignation is a blow to the PM – and not just because of his attack on her for “a failure of British statecraft not seen since the Suez crisis”.His departure will put more pressure on those ministerial colleagues who privately share his view that a second referendum is needed, to go.With both Johnsons voting against the withdrawal agreement, it will become even harder to get it through the Commons.SO will any of the Cabinet resign over Theresa May’s Brexit plan  At the moment, ministers believe not.One of those who spoke against the May approach at Cabinet tells me the mood of the meeting was “resigned rather than resigning”.Another predicts critics of what Mrs May is doing “will make their point, then retreat”.This is not to say people are happy. Penny Mordaunt, the International Development Secretary, warned that voters wanted a “definitive end point to Brexit” andthey didn’t get it, that risked “feeding a narrative of betrayal, fuelling Ukip”.In private, ministers rail against Mrs May and the way she is handling the negotiations. Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt has been heard to complain that the UK is making it far too obvious it is in a desperate hurry to get a deal.It is certainly true that by advertising its need for a quick agreement, the UK is almost inviting the EU to ask for more.Tellingly, there is renewed – and increasing – talk among ministers of having a new leader in place to do the next set of negotiations.There is little love for the backstop. And interestingly, Chancellor Philip Hammond argued in Cabinet this week it would be better to extend the transition than trigger the backstop.He argued that the backstop could do damage to supply chains and said “it could be better to extend the implementation period than have a bad backstop”.A problem with extending the implementation period is that it would mean free movement would continue – and the UK would still be sending huge amounts of money to Brussels every year.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: london stansted ryanair seized french authorities
story: The budget carrier was meant to take off on Thursday from Bordeaux Airport and fly to London Stansted Airport.French authorities stepped in and ordered the Boeing  to be impounded.They said the move was “a last resort”.Airport officials say Ryanair owes £,even though the French civil aviation authority wouldn’t say how much the sum was, BBC reports.The dispute relates to French subsidies paid to Ryanair between  and , which the European Commission deemed illegal.The French agency spokesman Eric Heraud said the regional authorities who gave the subsidies had been trying to recover the money for the past four years.They sent their final warning in May and after six months without response from Ryanair, authorities say they decided to act.The authority said the plane “will remain immobilised until the sum is paid”.One passenger said they had all gone through passport control and security and were told to turn around right before they stepped out on the tarmac.Boris Hejblum said: “The airport staff told us there was an issue with the plane.”He also said that no Ryanair staff members were available and the only communication they received were two text messages giving them a voucher for a sandwich, which didnt cover the cost of a sandwich, and that their flight was delayed.Hejblum added: “I found it strange that the police were the only ones giving us information.”The passengers were put on another flight and finally landed at London Stansted five hours late.Hejblum said: I would say we just took it as another Ryanair problem, having no information from them.When we found out about the seizure, I would say the general sentiment was to blame Ryanair for not complying with the law.The Sun Online has contacted Ryanair for comment.

title: cops are led by donkeys sun says
story: Don’t get us wrong. This country is blessed to have hard-working frontline coppers doing their best to keep us safe.One of their number — PC Keith Palmer, who died in the Westminster Attack last year — will be rightly honoured with a memorial in the Parliament he gave his le to protect.But their bosses  The Home Office  It’s hard to shake the impression our lions are led by donkeys.Perceived hate crimes are deemed more important than burglaries and low-level violence. Top cops send their rank and file off to do PR stunts for the latest virtue-signalling cause. Every day seems to bring new tales of criminals getting away scot-free.It’s no surprise we’ve lost control of our streets, not just in the capital, but across the country — where kne crime is increasing at a HIGHER rate than in London.Politicians must do more than hope to plug the dam with a bit more cash. They must rebuild a ing force.That may well involve moving mental health responsibilities to another arm of government, or slashing the bureaucracy police are stuck with.It may even be time for an independent commission to look at policing.But this sorry state of affairs shames our nation — and leaves us all vulnerable.“AT the going down of the sun, and in the morning, we will remember them...”The lines of the famous war poem have never been as true as they are this weekend,  years on from the end of an awful conflict that took millions of lives. There are some who say that a century later we should consign this conflict to history. We respectfully disagree.We must keep on teaching the war’s horrors and of the reconciliation since. From a continent that tore itself apart twice in just four decades, Europe is now bound by common and friendly ties — no matter whether a country is an EU member or not.On Sunday that will be made abundantly clear when the German president lays a wreath at the Cenotaph.It is a fitting gesture of remembrance, and of progress.JO Johnson is entitled to his view that the PM’s Brexit deal is a bit of a mess.We share many of his concerns. Mrs May has a way to go to convince us she really is bringing us true independence.But his call for a second referendum is deeply dangerous. The people have had their say.They would not take kindly to being told to change their minds by the very political elites they turned against the first time.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: musician on hold so long transcribes jingle hmrc
story: Alan Drever-Smith, , was in the middle of what ended up being a -minute phone call on October , when the jarring tune sparked creative mischief in the session musician.Alan, from Hull, East Yorkshire, labelled his decision to transcribe the jingle as boredom therapy.After hearing the same minute-long segment repeated over  times, he decided use his laptop to transcribe.He said: As a musician, I was giggling because it was such rubbish - the tune is jarring and its just horrible to listen to, its almost comical.Five minutes had passed, and I had my laptop in front of me, so I just had a spark of mischief after hearing that same tune repeated  times.Its quite mundane but its jazzy - which is kind of hilarious because its so out of place, its like they just slammed two completely dferent songs together.I wanted to seeId be able to transcribe the music in the time I was on hold, which I did in roughly  minutes.It was boredom therapy. I just thought it could make someone laughI transcribed it and posted it up, it was just silly really.I think the fact that the song just repeats itself is enough make people go insane.The classically-trained drummer received over  shares after posting the sheet music on Facebook - and admitted there were no hard feelings once he finally finished the call.He added: Ive heard Vivaldis Spring used quite often and thats a lovely tune, but its horric when its converted for hold music where its destroyed completely.Id definitely volunteer myself to make a new version, but I think any music is horricrepeated indefinitely.You never get the chance to listen to a song in its entirety, it just lasts a minute then starts over. story: The couple walk . miles from their home every day to make their visit to their favourite McDonald’s chain location in Southgate Street, Bath.Pauline said: We walk . miles every day to get here.We pop in for a coffee at .am and then go to look round the shops. At ish we come back for what we call a snack.”Tom said: We come in here seven days a week, every day.Other than when weve been on holiday we havent missed a day in  years.”Toms regular feast consists of a Big Mac while Pauline samples more of the menus iety depending on her mood.Pauline, said: We like coming back here every single day because of the friendliness.The staff is always so helpful - we even feel like part of the building - part of the furniture. title: council uk forces staff work from home every friday
story: Conservative-run Shropshire Council has told staff they will work from home from  noon on the last Friday of the month, and every Friday from January.Schools, museums, libraries and other amenities will not be affected by the move.Council leader Peter Nutting said a spending freeze had been agreed across the council because of the need to get this years budget under control.He said: An ever-increasing number of vulnerable people need support which has meant that our adults and childrens social care services are under more pressure than ever.Despite allocating a further £ million to Social Care for  , increasing demand in this area now suggests another £ million is required this year funding that we just dont have. This isnt just a Shropshire issue, its happening all over the country.We had hoped that the Budget would help with recognised pressures in social care. We expect to get some additional funding but it isnt going to be anywhere near the additional £ million cost for this year alone.Spending freezes delay expenditure on things like buying new equipment, where this can happen. We will of course try to minimise the impact on frontline services.We will also be encouraging staff to work more flexibly as part of our transition to mobile and agile working. We are not closed for business, we will simply be working in a dferent way.The GMB union said the planned shutdown of council offices on Friday afternoons had come out of the blue.GMB official Stuart Richards said: Following the financial collapse of Northamptonshire County Council, weve seen councils adopt increasingly desperate measures to cope with the Tory governments austerity cuts that have seen services cut to the bone.This bizarre move by Shropshire council comes completely out of the blue. There has been no consultation or discussion with trade unions and no one has an idea as to what this would actually mean for staff or how it would practically work.GMB has requested an urgent meeting with the council to try and understand what on earth they are doing here. Well be consulting our members closely on what steps well be taking in response.

title: aldi serving sub standard caviar
story: Aldi’s Christmas product was being promoted to attract middle-class shoppers.Its website encouraged customers to “add a touch of luxury” with its “exclusive, specially selected British caviar”. It is supplied by KC Caviar, of Garforth, West Yorkshire. But Kenneth Benning, of London Fine Foods, claimed the chain’s version was “not the real thing”.He said: “Real caviar is the raw salted roe of sturgeon fish that has not been treated.“KC Caviar’s product has been rinsed in saline solution and put through a calcium bath.“This encases the roe in a form of jelly that changes the molecular structure and increases its longevity.Real caviar spoils within days. Yet I bought from KC Caviar nearly  weeks ago and it has not yet spoilt.”Mr Benning, who owns a sturgeon farm, added: “This is confirmation that the roe has gone through molecular change and is not the real thing.”Last night the store hit back at the claim, saying: “Aldi’s primary local authority has confirmed this product is caviar.”

title: boxing legend chris eubank becomes us marshal
story: The -year-old is now a city marshal in Opelousas, Louisiana.Eubank has had no formal police training but is officially allowed to arrest people.The ex-world super-middleweight champ has been touring the Deep South, giving lectures on how to “peacefully defuse dficult situations”.A source said: “Chris is over the moon with his new roles and takes them very seriously. title: prince harry meghan markle the queen ww1 festival of remembrance armistice
story: Theresa May was also in attendance at the annual Festival of Remembrance ahead of tomorrows Armistice Day commemorations — marking  years since the Great War came to an end.The Royals, including The Queen, took in a performance from Sir Tom Jones and actress Sheridan Smith gave a touching rendition of Are You Just Sleeping to the packed hall.And the Royal family, dressed in black, gave a standing ovation to welcome the Cha Pensioners and as family members of hero servicemen walked onto the stage.BBC One tonight broadcast the event — organised by armed forces charity the Royal British Legion as a thank you to all who served, sacriced and changed our world.Thousands of audience members attending held aloft photographs of those who took part in the First World War.The Queen raised her right hand in acknowledgement twice after the crowd sang the national anthem and cheers were sent her way.And in emotional scenes, descendants stood in the middle of the Royal Albert Hall with pictures of their ancestors.Theresa May and her husband Philip held aloft photographs of two of her ancestors — including Private Hubert Brasier Grant, of the East Surrey Regiment, who died at Passchendaele in  aged .A photograph was also shown of the PMs grandfather Sergeant Major Tom Brasier, who served with the Kings Royal Rle Corps.He played a modern version of Leonard Cohens Hallelujah to a hushed crowd.Other famous faces attending included Defence Secretary Gavin Williamson and former Countdown presenter Carol Vorderman.A poignant citation, written for Saturday evening by childrens author Sir Michael Morpurgo, was read by Second World War pilot Colin Bell.He read: They came because country called, because they knew it had to be done, that unless they went to fight there could be no peace.And still today they come forward, our soldiers and sailors and airmen and women, a hundred years on. They come, carrying the torch for freedom, our freedom.The Last Post sounded before poppies began to fall to the floor, forming a poignant carpet of red.The hall was bathed in silence as the petals fluttered down, some falling on to the caps of servicemen and women standing below.Members of the public mingled with members of the armed forces in the centre of the hall after the service ended.Meanwhile events to mark the end of the Great War have been taking place around the world.Leaders including Donald Trump, French president Emmanuel Macron, German chancellor Angela Merkel took place earlier on Saturday.Tomorrow, Prince Charles will lead the nation in honouring the countrys war dead during the national service of remembrance.The Queen will observe the Whitehall commemorations from the Foreign and Commonwealth Office.And in a historic act of reconciliation, German President Frank-Walter Steinmeier will lay a wreath at the Cenotaph alongside the Prime Minister and other leading political and Royal figures.A service in Westminster Abbey will also be held, alongside events in Glasgow, Cardf and Belfast to honour our fallen soldiers.Earlier today a rain-soaked Prince Harry laid a wreath in a sombre pre-match commemoration ahead of Englands rugby clash with New Zealand.

title: sainsburys christmas advert 2018 tia grace hopes to be star
story: Adorable Tia Grace Isaac was plucked from obscurity to sing in the heart warming commercial shot by famed Hollywood director Michael Gracey.But the eight-year-old was so good that her mum now fears they won’t be able to shop at their local supermarket without being recognised – and producers are tipping her for big things.Telecommunications worker mother Judith, , reveals in an exclusive interview: “I’m very proud of Tia. She’s done so well and it’s hard to believe this is happening.“We are looking forward to getting together and having a party to watch the advert.We’ll be feeling excited and a little bit nervous to see her on screen, but very, very proud.“I don’t think Tia understands the concept that she is going to be famous. It’s a lot for her to take in.“People will recognise her in our local Sainsbury’s, because we’re always in there. And now she is the star of their advert!”The Sun on Sunday was given an exclusive behind-the-scenes preview of the new flick about a girl trying to find the nerves to sing the New Radical’s hit ‘You Get What You Give’ at her school’s Christmas show.A total of  ordinary children were involved in the eight days of filming in October at Stoke Newington Town Hall in north-east London.Tia’s talent was spotted by a teacher who sent off a video of her singing to a casting agency, who then showed it to Sainsbury’s producers working with Greatest Showman director Gracey.Yet the schoolgirl, from East Ham, east London, reveals she won the part despite being rejected for a slot on The Voice Kids.She said: “I’ve always wanted to be a singer and started singing when I was three. I would sing Twinkle Twinkle Little Star for my family and put on shows.“I would love to be a pop star one day. I was auditioning for The Voice Kids, but they said no, so this is my first lead role.“I don’t think it’s really sunk in yet. I can’t wait to see it on the TV.“I love the Greatest Showman so I kept asking Michael to sign autographs for me.”Gracey told The Sun on Sunday: “Tia was absolutely incredible and so funny as well.Whenever I gave her direction I would never be sureshe had taken it in – and then she would absolutely nail it.“She has an amazing voice that is so pure. One of the things I love about Tia is that she didn’t go to the normal theatre schools and so she is so natural.All the other kids were blown away by her voice and she has the potential to be a huge star.”

title: labour mp lives in social housing
story: Shadow development secretary Kate Osamor has faced intense criticism after it emerged that she promoted her son in his House of Commons job, regardless of his conviction for having £, of Class A drugs with intent to supply at Bestival in Dorset last year.Now the Sun on Sunday can reveal that Ms Osamor and her son Ishmael, , are living in social housing in Tottenham, north London - despite their earnings classing them ineligible by council guidelines.Haringey Council documents from  state that households earning in excess of £, are not eligible to apply for a social housing property.And it has been reported that , people are waiting for social housing in the borough - one of the poorest in Britain - and a further , are living in temporary accommodation due to the limited supply of properties.Ms Osamor, a close ally of Jeremy Corbyn, is paid a salary of £, plus expenses. And before he resigned from Haringey council last month he was entitled to claim at least £, a year in allowances from the council.Ishmael was previously a durector of two clothing companies and a second hand car sales business which was dissolved in September this year. He pleaded guilty to the drug charges on October , having brought ecstasy, cocaine, ketamine and cannabis to the music festival.Ishmael was spared prison after his barrister persuaded prosecutors he was not planning to make a profit from his £, haul of drugs.Judge Stephen Climie said the -year-old was lucky to avoid a four-year prison term and sentenced him to  hours of unpaid work instead and to pay £ prosecution costs.Osamor pleaded guilty to four drugs charges after his barrister Mohsin Zaidi struck a deal with the Crown Prosecution Service at Bournemouth Crown Court.The former Labour councillor was caught with g of ecstasy – a class A drug blamed for a string of deaths at music festivals – as well .g of cocaine, .g of ketamine and a trace of cannabis at Bestival in .Ms Osamor has denied wrongdoing in the row over her son.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: remembrance day services britain
story: All over Great Britain there will be services and parades to commemorate the contribution of British and Commonwealth servicemen and women involved in the two World Wars and later conflicts.From am: Throughout the day, huge ­portraits of local war heroes will be etched into the sand at  beaches around the UK for the Pages Of The Sea ­national event.am: Remembrance Sunday parade, Newcastle. A march from the civic centre to the Eldon Square war memorial which will be blanketed in knitted poppies..am: Remembrance Sunday parade, Manchester. Former forces ­personnel and charities will join a city-centre parade before a service at the war memorial..am: Remembrance Sunday parade, Leeds. The city’s Lord Mayor will be joining a military parade from Leeds City Museum to the war memorial in honour of those who lost their lives..am: Annual Remembrance ­Service, Liverpool. Thousands of ­poppies will drop from the roof of the city’s St George’s Hall after a parade and service led by veterans and ­community leaders..am: Remembrance Sunday parade, Birmingham. Ex-service personnel and other organisations march to pay ­tribute to lost members of the Armed Forces..pm: Beach tribute to Sgt Stanley McDougall, Weymouth, Dorset. Australian soldier Sgt McDougall won the VC for killing seven men and capturing a machine gun nest in France in March ..pm: Beach tribute to Capt Kenneth ­Grigson, East Looe, Cornwall. Capt ­Grigson, from nearby Pelynt, won the ­Military Cross and died fighting on the River Marne in July . He was ..pm: Beach tribute to Gurkha Kulbir Thapa, Lyme Regis, Dorset. Thapa won a ­Victoria Cross for helping a wounded soldier behind German lines. He later ed to Nepal and died in , aged ..am: Armistice procession, Edinburgh. Veterans, Armed Forces members and standard bearers will assemble on the Edinburgh Castle esplanade before ­marching to a ceremony at the city’s Stone of Remembrance..pm: In Edinburgh, poems by ­Wilfred Owen and Siegfried Sassoon will be read at a free concert on the site of the former Craiglockhart Military Hospital, where both men were among the soldiers treated there for shellshock.pm: Remembrance Service, Glasgow Cathedral. First Minister Nicola Sturgeon and Princess Anne will be attending..am: Beach tribute to Ellis Evans, ­Colwyn Bay, Conwy. The poet died at ­Passchendaele in  aged .pm: Welsh National Service of Remembrance, Cardf. A book containing the , names of Welsh servicemen and women who died in World War One will be presented at the service at Llandaff ­Cathedral..am: Armistice Commemoration, ­Belfast. Service at St Anne’s Cathedral.am: Wreath laying, Belfast. Northern Ireland Secretary Karen Bradley will be joining Irish Foreign Minister Simon Coveney to lay a wreath at the Cenotaph to remember all those from the island of ­Ireland who died.am: Bagpipers begin playing the ­traditional lament Battle’s O’er at , locations across the UK and Commonwealth countries to mark the beginning of  years since the Armistice..am: The Olympic Park in Stratford, East London will fall silent for a service of remembrance at the Shrouds Of The Somme memorial, featuring , shrouded figures representing the ­number of Tommies whose bodies were never found. Many of their families are expected to attend.am: National two-minute silence led by the Royal Family at the Cenotaph in ­Whitehall, London. Prince Charles will again lay a wreath on behalf of the Queen..am: More than , Royal British Legion veterans will march past the ­Cenotaph..pm: The Nation’s Thank You begins with the People’s Procession, in which , people whose relatives served in the Great War will leave Green Park and walk past the Cenotaph. It will take an hour for them all to finish the .mile route, after which they can place wreaths on the ­national war ­memorial..pm: International bell-ringing: Just as in , bells will ring out in cathedrals and churches in London and all over the UK and Europe to mark the end of the ­conflict.pm: Beefeaters at the Tower of London will lead the Last Flames ceremony.pm: The Queen will attend the National Service at Westminster Abbey to mark the centenary, with members of the Royal Family, the Prime Minister, other ­politicians and invited guests also in attendance.pm: A nationwide chain of , ­Beacons of Light will be lit, starting in Unst – the most ­northerly inhabited island in the UK – and stretching all the way to Cornwall..pm: Bells will ring once again as the ­beacons blaze throughout Britain and town criers in  towns and cities ­perform a “cry for peace”.The Armistice ceasefire agreement ended more than four years of bloody conflict – a war that remains one of the most costly in ­history, with around  million lives lost.Here, Graeme Cullord outlines the main points in the conflict.WORLD War One was set in motion on June  when ­Austro-Hungarian emperor Franz ­Ferdinand was assassinated while visiting Bosnian ­capital Sarajevo.Serbian secret military police had supplied the weapon as Serbia tried to exert control of its neighbours.Austria-Hungary — backed by Germany — declared war on Serbia, which had formed an ­alliance with Russia and France. When the Russians and French threatened to get involved, the conflict escalated quickly.Britain ordered ­Germany not to enter Belgium as its ­soldiers marched on France and after an “unsatisfactory reply,” declared war on August .But by the end of the summer the German army had got within  miles of Paris.In December an informal   truce   allow- ed troops to enjoy a Christmas football game in no man’s land — but the war was far from over.The main theatre of war took place on what was known as the Western Front.Some of the most brutal battles were fought there amid  miles of barbed wire-covered tren-ches which were regularly battered by artillery bombardments.Machine gun placements cut down brave soldiers whenever they raised their heads.The Battle of ­Gallipoli began in February as combined British, French, Indian, New Zealand, Australian and ­Canadian forces fought German ally the Turkish Ottoman Empire.The early Allied attack, led by future Premier Winston Churchill, ended in humiliating defeat.The Battle of Jutland was the ­biggest naval conflict of the war and ­pitted the British fleet against the Germans and their “Dreadnought” battleships. Around  ships and , troops were involved in the epic North Sea ­confrontation that began in May.Both sides suffered heavy losses with the Royal Navy losing  ships and more than , men to the Germans’  ships and , men.July saw the start of the Battle of the Somme, a massive joint-British and French operation to drive the Germans out of northern France.However, an advance of , men to capture the enemy trenches failed, despite a seven-day bombardment beforehand.On the first day , men were killed, making it the bloodiest day in British military ­history. Over the next  days no more than three square miles of enemy territory were taken.The Third Battle of Ypres, named after a Belgian town, became notorious for the rain and mud that clogged rles, halted tanks and led to men and horses drowning.Also known as the Battle of ­Passchendaele after a village that was captured by our troops, this battle saw , British ­casualties and , German.By spring, many ­Germans felt sure of victory as their forces crossed the Western Front towards Paris.But the advance cost , casualties and their th Army ran out of supplies.At the same time hundreds of thousands of American soldiers poured into France after the US declared war on Germany. Between March and July, the Germans suffered a million casualties and the tide had turned.The Hundred Days Offensive began in August and the Germans began surrendering in large numbers. By November the war was over.The first Armistice Day was held by King George V in the grounds of Buckingham Palace on November , . The same year, a two-minute silence was proposed to remember the millions who died.Today, a two-minute Remembrance Sunday silence to commemorate both world wars is held at am at the Cenotaph in London.THE World War One Centenary Roll of Honour supplement in today’s Sun on Sunday carries the names of readers’ relatives who served in the Great War.Here, Joshua Salisbury reveals some of the heartbreaking and inspiring stories of those who bravely fought in the conflict.Mel Hewards grandfather Ralph Ellis ­suffered more than most ­during the war, ­losing four of his seven brothers — three of them within just three months of each other in . Their bodies have never been ed home.Mel’s great uncle, Pte Walter Ellis was killed in Iraq on June ,  Pte ­Richard Henry Ellis died of wounds received in France on July  Pte Ben Ellis was killed in action at High Wood, France, on September  and Cpl ­Percival Ellis died from wounds received in Flanders on April , .Every Armistice Day, Mel meets with her extended family in a pub near Exeter to remember their lost ­relatives.She said: “These days Ralph would have been diagnosed with PTSD or at least taken back from the ­front line on hearing of his ­brothers’ deaths. But times were dferent back then.”Armistice comes with mixed ­feelings for Pamela Fairley, , of Smallfield, Surrey, as her great-uncle Thomas Highgate was the first soldier to be shot at dawn, on September , , for desertion.“He must have been so scared,” says grandmother-of-two Pamela. “He was young and came from a really impoverished background.”After the war, -year-old Thomas’s name was omitted from memorials despite his service in the deadly Battle of Mons, Belgium. He was ­pardoned, alongside  other ­soldiers, in .Pamela says: “Thomas might have been shot at dawn but he will never be ­forgotten.”They are worth protecting. Every British serviceman has fought in the name of those principles.Sergeant Jack Cottrell helped keep his fellow soldiers’ spirits up with his musical talent, says his son Peter.“He never spoke much about his time serving but I know he’d travel round the country entertaining the troops, to keep morale high.”Jack’s talent later meant he penned some of George Formby’s greatest hits including Baby, Why Don’t Women Like Me , ­Sitting On The Ice At The Ice Rink and I Could Make A Good Living At That.Peter says: “Dad was only in his ­fties when he passed away and while his musical ­talent has skipped every generation since then, I’m incredibly proud of his efforts during the war.”Private Norman Harvey was just  when he lied about his age in order to join the Royal Inniskilling ­Fusiliers in . He went on to be one of the youngest ­recipients of the Victoria Cross in the war.He died fighting near ­Palestine in  after enlisting for the ­Second World War.His great-nephew John Savage, who recently met up with more than  relatives to celebrate Norman’s achievement, recalls: “Mum always talked about him with pride.“I remember her telling me that when he came home with his Victoria Cross, he was put straight on a cart and wheeled around the town for ­everyone to see and hear.”Norman’s VC citation details his bravery while fighting at Ingoyghen, Belgium, in October , after ­he rushed forward single-handedly to take on  enemy soldiers.He is remembered with a statue and a street, Norman Harvey VC Close, in his home town of Newton Le Willows, Lancs.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: ww1 solider lost writing second lieutenant hamish
story: Second Lieutenant Hamish Mann’s death in  during the Battle of Arras left his family so devastated that they could barely talk about him.His great-niece and great-nephew grew up knowing little about the man who died just after his st birthday on a French battlefield.But an incredible discovery  years after his death has kept his memory alive — and will bring his writings from the frontline to a new generation.By chance, his relatives Rosemary and Robert Stewart found a cherrywood box containing his moving accounts of le on the frontline in their mum’s house and, along with author Jacquie Buttriss, they’ve turned it into a book.Jacquie explained: “When I saw it I was so impressed — I had never come across such a comprehensive collection of First World War writings, fresh from the trenches. And I just thought they were wonderful.”Hamish, from Edinburgh, joined the Black Watch shortly after his th birthday when war broke out in , despite having a heart condition.All siblings Robert and Rosemary had to remember him by was a photo in their gran’s house — and the family always seemed reluctant to speak about their fallen relative, as many were after the war.Robert, , said: “When Rosie and I were kids we used to stay with granny, Isabel Mann, in Edinburgh and we’d say, ‘Well, who is this person ’She was obviously very upset about it even then, which would be  or .“But nothing was ever forthcoming. It was simply he died in the war.”It wasn’t until years later, when the siblings were clearing out their mum’s house in Peeblesshire, Scotland, following her move to a nursing home, they came across Hamish’s trunk.Rosemary, , said: “We found few bits and pieces that were of great interest, the main one being the trunk with Hamish’s things it.”With the house sale imminent, the pair were under pressure to clear the property — and were close to selling all the contents of the loft for just £, despite one box they found being left unopened.Dad-of-two Robert said: “On the last day I said, ‘yikes, we still haven’t dealt with that box’. So that was the moment critique.”Rosemary, a music teacher in Edinburgh, opened the box to discover notebooks and letters belonging to their great-uncle Hamish Mann.She took everything home and tried to make some sense of all the papers.She said: “All the papers were mixed up so you might begin reading a poem and find it finished halfway.And the next piece of paper you came across was part of a funny play he’d written at school. I laid all out on the floor and for several months didn’t do much .”They turned to friend and writer Jacquie, who started researching Hamish’s background.She discovered he’d been ill as a child suffering from an enlarged heart, also known as cardio myopathy.The author said: “He was bedridden for a good year during which time he wrote about a hundred poems or so.He made good use of his bedridden time but it was very hard for him.”Jacquie found out he’d worked for a repertory company as a teenager and performed on the Lyceum Stage in Edinburgh, where he also wrote a number of plays.And an old copy of Stage Magazine revealed he’d been named one of their playwrights of the year aged just .A year after he received the theatrical honour, war broke out.An extract from Hamish Mann’s writings in A Muddy Trench: A Sniper’s BulletThat newly captured trench I shall never forget, nor the anguish I felt as we filed slowly in, through the clinging mud in the misty light of the moon. It was the most repellent sight I have ever seen, and the absolute horror of it was not in any way lessened by the splendid atmosphere of noble sacrice that reigned everywhere.It was almost impossible in many cases to distinguish between the dead and the living, so motionless did the latter lie in their exhaustion, after the terrible work of taking the trench. Some of the bodies were dreadful, seated on the floor of the trench in natural positions, their faces fallen back, upturned, ghostly-white, cheeks sunken, teeth gleaming through the grin of death that had parted their pale lips.Others were face-downwards, clots of blood on their unorms, gashed and bedraggled, half sunk in the mud — just as they had fallen in that last supreme moment. A few were terribly mangled.One had had his body from the waist upwards blown completely away, and the poor, pitul legs were lying against the sloping parados of that unspeakable trench.Wounded were littered everywhere, and it rent one’s heart to hear them moan and rave in the delirium of their suffering, or cry aloud as someone stumbled against them in the dark. It was impossible not to do this, for many of these wretched men were almost smothered in the sucking slimeStill we filed along, all but sickened by the nauseating stench of decomposing human bodies, a distinctive smell which is even now in my nostrils.Hamish — real name Alexander James — was  but his health condition meant he didn’t have to sign-up.Instead, he lied on forms about his fitness, sought a second opinion from medics and went to war.Rosemary said: “He always said he wasn’t so interested in being a soldier, but he was a patriot and always wanted to do his best for his country, so had this huge sense of duty.He had one consultant who failed him and said his heart wasn’t up to it. However, he tried again.“I think the doctor on that day didn’t have the time to go into things in too much depth and he said, ‘this time I got by’.After signing up, he was sent to Northern France in , arriving first in the Somme before being stationed throughout the region, including billets at Gouy-Servins and Mingoval.He wrote his last poem on the morning of April , after musing about his fallen friends and wonderinghe’d be next.Three days later his battalion marched to Arras, their objective was to capture the enemy’s front line.But Hamish was hit full force by a German shell and he died on the battlefield.The book has brought together Hamish’s story along with his poetry penned from the heart of the conflict and his other works.Jacquie added: “You feel you are there with him. And that is not always a good thing.But you do and it makes such a dference. And he was so young.”Hamish’s family are so proud to have been abe to piece together his work and bring it to a new audience.Rosemary said: “We all felt that it was our duty to honour him by doing something about all this writing.We’re so pleased and relieved people are showing an interest in the book.”Robert, now based in Eastbourne, East Sussex, and a retired purchasing manager, said: added: “He is one of millions of soldiers who died in that war and as a very young person I suppose I just always thought, well this is just another one.“I say that not flippantly but how do you draw attention to one of millions of people who died in the war “However, he just had something  for the world to know.”Muddy Trench: A Sniper’s Bullet: Hamish Mann, Black Watch, Officer-Poet, -, by Jacquie Buttriss is out on hardback on November  priced £

title: stop praying silence from charles
story: But close your eyes and imagine, for a moment, knowing from childhood exactly what job you are going to do — because you have no choice about whether or not you actually want to do it.And imagine, then, having to wait for that job to start until you are the age when most people are hanging up their work boots and starting to claim a pension.It’s impossible, right  But the Prince of Wales — the man who was born to be king — has known since the age of four that he would one day have to step into his mother’s shoes. And what a mother.They say no one is irreplaceable but I think she is — which must be such a lot of pressure for him. In short, he has spent his entire le waiting for his mum to die before he can start his dream job.And in the meantime his le, in some ways, is on hold. He was not allowed to marry the woman he loved and was instead forced into a loveless marriage.And every time he so much as expresses an opinion about anything, he is denounced as being “meddling”.So it’s no wonder that in Prince, Son And Heir, the BBC documentary this week marking his th birthday, Charles was quick to quell concerns that he would be a “meddling” or activist king, saying: “I’m not that stupid.”Declaring the role of sovereign and heir to be dferent, he said he is aware of the constraints he will encounter as king, and says his behaviour will change.I can see why he is saying that, given the amount of criticism that has come his way over the years. But when you think that he was campaigning about issues such as the environment and single-use plastic long before anyone  got on the bandwagon, it might be better to see him as a trailblazer than a meddler.I admire that he has a voice.And when he is king I think he should use it — not be silenced by the pressure of the role.He has a very broad range of knowledge and he is absolutely passionate. We live in a society where everyone has their say — so why shouldn’t he In fact, I thinkhe visited Europe he might help with Brexit.There is no doubt the Queen is a hard act to follow — when the time comes, that is. Now Charles is  he is the longest serving heir to the throne in history. And he may have years to go, as the Queen looks and sounds fantastic .But we should stop maligning Charles and start supporting him.He is a good man and there is no doubt he is dedicated to the job. He is mature enough to know how to do the job well and he certainly knows what is expected of him.He has brought up two fantastic sons that any parent would be proud of.And he really is passionate about changing the world for the better.It has been more than  years since he set up his Prince’s Trust charity.Last year alone it helped nearly , young people get into education, training and jobs. It is simply fantastic.He is deeply committed to his fantastic we, who is very down-to-earth and great fun .He is also passionate about promoting women’s issues, so whatever you think of him you must give him credit for that.I believe very strongly in the monarchy. I would do anything the Queen asked me to do.The Royal Family are a great thing for our country and something to be very proud of.In a world of increasing uncertainty, they are this country’s rock and foundation. We should all get behind Charles and celebrate him as our future king.Apart from anything , we need all the stability we can get. ANYONE living in London will be unsurprised to hear that there are now a record number of people sleeping rough there.Figures show there were , rough sleepers in the capital between July and September – the first time the total has exceeded , in a three-month period.It’s awful and it’s shocking to see people sitting in the cold begging for money.And it’s hard to know how to help. Of course, the temptation is to give money but obviously that’s just a short-term fix.Night shelters are a good short-term solution. Buthomeless people don’t get involved with a network that can really help them, it’s unlikely their circumstances will ever change.My husband Paul volunteers with the fantastic charity West London Mission . It offers homeless people a hot shower, new clothes, a meal and a decent night’s sleep.But it also offers access to project workers who will help people change their circumstances.Its aim is to empower and help homeless people become part of a community, because that’s the start of them getting off the streets, into accommodation, then into work.There are so many reasons that people become homeless. Some have lost their job and can’t afford rent, or they’ve fallen out with family and turn to drink and drugs.They might have mental or physical health problems, a history of abuse or a dficult childhood moving between foster homes.But where there is le, there is hope. Paul has been working with one guy who was homeless and hopelessly addicted to drugs.But, over time, he has got clean, found a place to live and, last week, got a job at a restaurant, which is what he was doing before he got involved in drugs.He’s got his le back, basically. It does happen.Soyou are worried about homelessness, think about donating to an organisation such as WLM. Better yet, volunteer your time and skills.Even just helping someone to fill out a form, which can be incredibly dficult for some people, can make a huge dference and is so rewarding.TODAY is Remembrance Day and I wear my poppy with pride. This year I will particularly recognise all the true heroes from World War One. I thank them for their service, and remember we are always in their debt.It is so important we never forget the sacrice they made and the bravery they showed.I doubt there will ever be another generation like them. AS a rule, I like to live and let live. But I really had to roll my eyes at the story of -year-old Dutch pensioner Emile Ratelband, “who identies as a -year-old” and is fighting to legally change his age by  years so he can get more work and attract more women on Tinder.Emile, above, was born on March , , but says he feels at least  years younger and wants to change his birth date to March , .His argument is thattransgender people are allowed to change sex, he should be allowed to change his date of birth because doctors said he has the body of a -year-old.So does that meanI feel like a supermodel inside, I can I get my job title legally amended Or maybe at  I could identy as  so I can have access to my pension SO the six men arrested for burning an effigy of Grenfell Tower are in hiding and relying on friends and relatives to bring in food and drink. Still, they are yet to speak out – or apologise.What beggars belief is not just that these sick men thought that no one would notice nor care when this footage emerged on social media – but really that they are unhinged enough to do it in the first place.I’m pretty sure about one thing, though. No matter what consequences they will face for their actions from the law, they will never, ever live this down in the eyes of the world – and nor should they.I’m talking about Michael Douglas, . When he was awarded with a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame for more than  years in the entertainment industry, he gave his father, Kirk, a kiss on the lips to celebrate.In my experience there comes an age when your kids don’t want to kiss you – particularly on the lips and particularly your dad.It’s part and parcel of growing up that your kids don’t even want you to breathe, let alone kiss them.In fact, everything you do embarrasses them. But, given that Kirk Douglas is , maybe it’s just a reminder that things come full circle.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: thousands of leicester city fans take part in march to remember chairman
story: The chairman was one of five people killed in a helicopter crash in a car park outside the stadium on  October.Kaveporn Punpare, Nusara Suknamai, pilot Eric Swaffer and his partner Izabela Roza Lechowicz also lost their lives and were remembered by Leicester fans. Saturday marked the clubs first home game since his death. The team drew - against Burnley.The club gave every supporter at the match a free scarf, pin badge and programme, tucked under their seats inside the stadium. During the silence, the players gathered together, opposite members of the club staff who wore black, while fans held the white scarves reading "Mr Chairman".The two-minute silence also marked  years since the end of the First World War. Players shirts featured the chairmans name, with Khun Vichai, forever in our hearts encircling the club badge.The squad also laid their own shirts down inside the stadium before the match, alongside the fan tributes. The club staff had the huge task this week of moving the thousands of tributes and flowers which had been laid outside the stadium, putting them into the car park to allow access. The club has announced plans to commission a statue of the chairman to be installed outside the stadium.His son Khun Aiyawatt wrote in a souvenir programme for Saturdays match: "We will never be able to repay what he did for us - for me as his son, us as his family, everyone connected to Leicester City and beyond - but we are committed to honouring his memory and upholding his legacy. "Our continued growth as a club, our state-of-the-art new training ground and our planned stadium expansion will help realise his vision for Leicester City.

title: brexit news three more ministers
story: NewsBrexit news: Three more ministers set to quit as Theresa May faces fresh turmoilEXCLUSIVE: Sources say three ministers are in “advanced talks” to follow his lead and plunge Theresa May’s government into fresh turmoilShareCommentsByKeir Mudie:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsTheresa May’s government is facing fresh turmoil "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailDowning Street is braced for further resignations after Boris Johnson’s brother Jo sensationally quit over Brexit. Sources say three ministers are in “advanced talks” to follow his lead and plunge Theresa May’s government into fresh turmoil. One insider said: “They are shyplanning when exactly is the right time to do it. Jo set the news agenda by releasing his decision on Friday evening. Everyone was a bit surprised. “The logical thing to do would have been to quit after the Brexit Cabinet meeting. So it’s important they get this right.” Mr Johnson, who backed Remain during the  campaign, quit his role as Transport Minister.  In his resignation statement, he said he believed the public should have a second referendum. And he blasted the PM’s handling of Brexit negotiations. Mr Johnson is the sixth minister to quit over Brexit since Mrs May’s January reshuffle. Three were Leavers, including Boris. The others were Remainers. Mr Johnson’s decision piles more pressure on Mrs May, who faces a crunch week in Parliament. Tory MP Anna Soubry, also a Remain campaigner, said: “Jo isn’t the only minister who shares these views and I hope others will follow his lead.” One insider said: “We know there are three ministers in talks but it will be interesting to see what the Cabinet does.  “Andrea Leadsom and Esther McVey will be thinking about it. And then Sajid Javid and Jeremy Hunt will be having a look at their positions. “In some ways Dominic Raab is the key one. If the Brexit Secretary goes – again – what does it say about the whole process ” A backbench source said Jo Johnson’s departure was a “real blow” for Mrs May, adding: “It shows there is another front opening up. We all knew the Brexiteers who have dug in and are prepared to vote against whatever deal she brings back from Brussels. “But now you have a fresh set of Remain people who are equally shyhardline when it comes to the shynegotiations. This is real trouble.”

title: brit sweatshop workers earning little
story: NewsBrit sweatshop workers earning as little as £ an hour making copycat celeb outfitsEXCLUSIVE: Cheap imitations of expensive designer outfits worn on red carpets or catwalks by actresses, models and other stars now find their way online within days of making public debutsShareCommentsByNick SommerladNigel NelsonPolitical EditorAlan Selby:,  NOV NewsMirrorman Nick Sommerlad in talk with illegal during our investigation "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWorkers toil for as little as pound an hour making copycat clothes to feed our “fast fashion” craze for dressing like celebs. Cheap imitations of expensive designer outfits worn on red carpets or catwalks by actresses, models and other stars now find their way online within days of making public debuts. However they are not made in sweltering sweatshops in Asia but the back streets of Leicester. Fans are desperate to look like celebs such as Kim Kardashian, Michelle Keegan and Paris Hilton but cannot afford the same price tag. Speed is essential as some pop-up internet shops won’t wait a month for stock to come from the Far East. So there is a roaring trade in churning out instant copies which sell for as little as pound – while many workers do not get paid anything like the pound. minimum wage. The Sunday Mirror investigated as MPs were told wage abuses were an open secret in Leicester’s garment industry, a huge part of which was “a country within a country” flouting labour law.  One illegal worker called Sunny told us he had worked under the noses of auditors supposed to enforce “ethical” working conditions and even fled out of back doors to dodge immigration officials, Sunny, , originally from Gudjerat, India, arrived in Leicester in . He said: “I was trained as a machinist for pound. an hour. I still work for pound shysometimes. I have worked in  to  dferent factories. I work  hours, six days a week, sometimes Sundays too. “The most I have earned is pound. but it is normally pound. to pound.. “There are lots of people like me. I’d say that in every factory of  people you would have three or four illegals.”  Leicester has  textile factories which can make a million clothes a week for booming online retailers. Most do comply with the law – but a number of small places ignore the rules. Bosses blame retailers who demand rapid deliveries, impose huge fines for being late and haggle over mere pennies. They also say retailers do not pay them for up to  days and charge for sending back unsold stock. Factory owner Saeed Khilji, chairman of the Textile Manufacturer Association of Leicestershire, employs workers legally but says demand for celeb outfits often drives production. He said: “If an outfit goes viral, retailers race to get their copy online.  “Ten years ago manufacturers could make pound profit from a dress but these days they would be lucky to make p. “None of the retailers are giving us an ethical price. An extra pound or pound. on a garment would sort everything out. Instead they squeeze us for pennies.” He added: “If they don’t sell everything, they send it back and charge us for the carriage. If we are an hour or  minutes late with delivery they fine us pound. I have been told of one retailer who is making poundmillion a year from fines.” Firms have complained that the new “Fast Forward” factory inspections, to which a number of major labels are signed up, is onerous. One said: “They want us to give contracts to our workers but they won’t give us contracts. When they are not busy, the factories can’t survive.”  Alkesh Kapadia, of Barcode Fashion, employs  workers in two factories and pays them the minimum wage. He said: “Retailers threaten, ‘If you can’t do it we will find someone ’. I say, ‘How does that work ’ If I can’t do it, how can anyone  ’” Another manufacturer said: “I used to make pound. to pound profit per garment. Now it might be p.” Two weeks ago the Commons shyEnvironmental Audit Committee heard evidence about sustainability in the fashion industry. Investigative journalist Sarah O’Connor told MPs: “If you go around the high street you will be amazed to see how many dresses say “Made in the UK” but cost pound, pound, pound.  “I wondered, ‘How on earth is this possible ’ The answer is that basically, in a huge chunk of Leicester’s garment industry, labour law does not apply.” Some retailers have joined the Ethical Trading Initiative where shyfactories undergo stricter audits, but others have not. Sarah O’Connor said: “One of the biggest would be Boohoo. They source an awful lot in Leicester. “They are not members of the ETI.” Sarah Ditty, of Fashion Revolution, told MPs: “There are a lot of brands that are not really disclosing any shyinformation about what they are doing.” MPs have called on five leading online-only fashion retailers – Boohoo, Amazon, Asos, PrettyLittleThing and Missguided – to give evidence as part of their inquiry into the industry. Boohoo told the Sunday Mirror it insists on suppliers “acknowledging responsibility” for paying a living wage and conducts third-party audits. It also denied fining for late shydeliveries or ing unsold items and said it pays suppliers within  days. Missguided said: “We’re proud of what we’ve been doing through our membership of the ETI to address industry issues.” ASOS declined to comment but there is no suggestion it does not adhere to industry rules.

title: couple eat mcdonalds every day
story: NewsCouple eat McDonalds every day for  years - and rubbish claims its fatteningTom and Pauline Jones, both in their s, visit their local McDonalds in Bath every day - and for a heartwarming reasonShareCommentsByLiam Trim:,  NOV NewsTom and Pauline Jones have visited McDonalds in Bath almost every day for  years in a row "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA couple in their s have eaten at McDonalds every day for  years and say the idea the takeaway makes people fat is rubbish. Tom and Pauline Jones, from Bath, have made popping into the Southgate McDonald’s part of their daily routine.The long term residents were the guests of honour on Wednesday as the fast food restaurant marked its th birthday in the city.Tom, , told Bath Live: “We come in here seven-days-a week, every day.“Other than when we’ve been on holiday we haven’t missed a day in  years.”Even on trips away from their home city the couple have sought out the familiar comfort of McDonald’s, according to -year-old Pauline.  She said: “Even on holiday we used to look for McDonald’s. We’ve been to ones in Exmouth, Exeter, Weston-super-Mare and Bristol.” The married pair, who have both been retired for around  years, have no hesitation in recommending McDonald’s to others. Tom even said that one of the charges levelled against the takeaway chain by critics - that much of its food can lead to people being overweight - is wrong. “I just want to say that all this nonsense about McDonald’s making you fat is rubbish, he said. Look at us.” But the fact Tom and Pauline remain slim and fit in their eighties may be down to the other parts of their daily routine.  Every day they enjoy walking into the centre of Bath. But explaining their visit to McDonald’s, Pauline added: “We walk . miles every day to get here. “We pop in for a coffee at .am and then go to look round the shops. “At ish we come back for what we call a snack.” Tom almost always goes for a Big Mac, while Pauline samples more of the menu’s iety - enjoying the Big Mac like her husband, but also chicken nuggets or a BBQ chicken wrap, depending on her mood.  “It’s the friendliness,” Pauline said. “The staff are always so helpful.“We feel like part of the building - part of the furniture.“We always feel as though they know who we are and they’re so kind.“Mind you I always say thank you, and I think that goes a long way.“It’s like a second home to us.” The couple are not “pub people”, Pauline added, and they value the community they find at McDonald’s.But there is a time of the day when they’re not as keen on visiting.“We like it in the mornings when it isn’t so busy,” Pauline said. “It’s a bit hectic at dinner time.”McDonald’s franchisee Paul Pearson, who owns and operates the Southgate and Weston Lock Retail Park restaurants in Bath, invited Tom and Pauline to the cutting of a cake on November  to mark the Southgate branch’s th birthday.He said Tom and Pauline were the perfect symbols of the dference McDonald’s could make in a community.

title: dramatic moment man waving samurai
story: NewsDramatic moment man waving samurai sword stopped by armed police who Taser himPolice detained the man following the shocking incident on Rectory Road in Basildon, Essex, on Saturday afternoonShareByNeil MurphyHannah Kane:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsArmed police confronted the man outside a pharmacy in Basildon, Essex "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailDramatic images show how armed police confronted a man waving a samurai sword in Essex this afternoon.Officers swooped on Rectory Road in Basildon at around .pm on Saturday after being called to the scene over concerns for the welfare of the man. CCTV shows officers burst out of their vehicle and point their weapons at the man as he raised the large kne over his head. He then dropped to the ground as police moved closer to carry out the arrest in front of shocked bystanders. Reports say the man was tasered after he refused to put his weapon down. A cordon was put in place around the nearby pharmacy, with officers carrying out investigation work.  Footage from the scene shows a samurai sword being picked up by officers. A witness at the scene said: “It’s scary, I was just walking my dog and saw the cordons up. “It must frighten the shop people, thinking this is going on nearby. “You have to have eyes at the back of your head.” Another witness Rupan Shan said: We saw a guy outside with a big sword. We called the police and they where hear within minutes. We were told to lock up the shop by police so for our customers safety. We locked them inside too. There were children here. We were all so shocked to see what we saw.We watched out the window as it happened. The police shouted at him to drop the kne and then then tasered him and took him away.  A spokesman for Essex Police said: We were called at .pm on Saturday, November  to concerns for the welfare of a man in the Rectory Road area of Pitsea who was reported to have a sword and was making threats. Officers attended and a man was detained.

story: NewsMeghan Markle joins Queen in tribute to fallen heroes at Festival of RemembranceMeghan Markle, Prince William and Kate were joined by Prince Harry as they attended the event to mark the centenary of the ArmisticeShareCommentsByNeil Murphy:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsMeghan Markle is attending the event tonight with husband Harry "Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMembers of the Royal Family are attending the Festival of Remembrance in a poignant tribute to those who sacriced their lives in Britains military conflicts. The event, which is organised by the Royal British Legion, marks  years since the Armistice which brought World War I to a close.
